query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Dal centro al cerchio, e sì dal cerchio al centro 2 movesi l’acqua in un ritondo vaso, 3 secondo ch’è percosso fuori o dentro:
4 ne la mia mente fé sùbito caso 5 questo ch’io dico, sì come si tacque 6 la glorïosa vita di Tommaso,
7 per la similitudine che nacque 8 del suo parlare e di quel di Beatrice, 9 a cui sì cominciar, dopo lui, piacque:
10 «A costui fa mestieri, e nol vi dice 11 né con la voce né pensando ancora, 12 d’un altro vero andare a la radice.
query.result:
**English:**
1 From the center to the rim, and so from the rim to the center, 2 the water moves in a round vessel, 3 according to whether it is struck from outside or from within:
4 in my mind this that I say suddenly happened, 5 as soon as the glorious life of Thomas fell silent,
6 because of the similarity that arose 7 between his speech and that of Beatrice, 8 to whom it pleased me to begin speaking after him:
9 "This man has need, and he does not tell you 10 either with his voice or even in his thoughts, 11 to go to the root of another truth.
**Cornish:**
1 A'gan kres dhe'n kelgh, ha henna a'gan kelgh dhe'n kres, 2 yma an dowr a-hedhi y'n lester krug, 3 avel henna a veu skeus a-ves po dhe'n-ves:
4 Y'n ow mynnerth henna a wrug kas marow, 5 pub tra'th pan veu an byw a-wrug tewes, 6 an byw a-wrug tewes, 7 rag an hevelep a veu genys, 8 ynter y lavarow ha henna a-wrug leverel Beatrice, 9 neb dhe henna y'm eus leverel wosa henna:
10 "An den ma eus owth, ha ny leverel dhe'wgh, 11 na gans y lavar na gans y brederi, 12 dhe'n gwiryow erel dhe'n wreydh."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Come, da più letizia pinti e tratti, 20 a la fïata quei che vanno a rota 21 levan la voce e rallegrano li atti,
22 così, a l’orazion pronta e divota, 23 li santi cerchi mostrar nova gioia 24 nel torneare e ne la mira nota.
query.result:
**English:**
19 As, urged and drawn by greater joy, 20 those who go in a ring at times 21 raise their voices and gladden their movements,
22 so, at the prompt and devout prayer, 23 the holy circles showed new joy 24 in their circling and in the wondrous melody.
**Cornish:**
19 Avel, a-les moy letyssyow, 20 henna neb a wra y'n dans, 21 a wra sevel aga lavarow ha aga oberow,
22 Henna, dhe'n pedn prest ha devos, 23 an kelgh sansow a-dhyskwedhes letyssyow nowydh, 24 y'n aga troha ha y'n an nota a-veur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Qual si lamenta perché qui si moia 26 per viver colà sù, non vide quive 27 lo refrigerio de l’etterna ploia.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Whoever laments that he dies here 26 in order to live up there, has not seen there 27 the refreshment of the eternal rain.
**Cornish:**
25 Pyth yw a wra dhe'n leverel henna yw marow ama, 26 rag dhe'n bewnes y'n henna, ny wrug efan gweles 27 an sywora a'gan glav byth bys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Quell’ uno e due e tre che sempre vive 29 e regna sempre in tre e ’n due e ’n uno, 30 non circunscritto, e tutto circunscrive,
31 tre volte era cantato da ciascuno 32 di quelli spirti con tal melodia, 33 ch’ad ogne merto saria giusto muno.
query.result:
**English:**
28 That one and two and three who always lives 29 and always reigns in three and in two and in one, 30 not circumscribed, and circumscribes all,
31 was sung three times by each 32 of those spirits with such melody, 33 that it would be a just reward for any merit.
**Cornish:**
28 An onan ha dewdha ha tre a vew byw 29 ha'gas rewl bys vythkweth yn tre ha'gas dewdha ha'gas onan, 30 heb kesroedhys, ha kesroedhys pub tra,
31 teyr gweyth o kanas gans pub onan 32 a'n sperys na gans henna melodi, 33 henna a via bos mar dhe pub bravder.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 E io udi’ ne la luce più dia 35 del minor cerchio una voce modesta, 36 forse qual fu da l’angelo a Maria,
37 risponder: «Quanto fia lunga la festa 38 di paradiso, tanto il nostro amore 39 si raggerà dintorno cotal vesta.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And I heard in the light more divine 35 of the lesser circle a modest voice, 36 perhaps like that of the angel to Mary,
37 answering: “As long as the feast 38 of paradise shall last, so long our love 39 shall radiate around such a garment.”
**Cornish:**
34 Ha'gas kovyn ynwedh ynwedh moy 35 a'n kethledh bianna onan leveryans gosek, 36 marteth henwys a'n el dhe Mari,
37 ow responsel: “Kemmys hi a vydh hir an goel 38 a baradys, kemmys hi a vydh hir an karanteth 39 a wra a-dro dhe'n jileth ma.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 La sua chiarezza séguita l’ardore; 41 l’ardor la visïone, e quella è tanta, 42 quant’ ha di grazia sovra suo valore.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Its brightness follows the ardor; 41 the ardor the vision, and that is as great 42 as the grace that exceeds its worth.
**Cornish:**
40 Y sklerder a sew an tanow; 41 an tanow an welas, ha henna yw kemmys, 42 avel an gras a wra a-ugh y werth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Tanto mi parver sùbiti e accorti 62 e l’uno e l’altro coro a dicer «Amme!», 63 che ben mostrar disio d’i corpi morti:
64 forse non pur per lor, ma per le mamme, 65 per li padri e per li altri che fuor cari 66 anzi che fosser sempiterne fiamme.
query.result:
**English:**
61 So sudden and alert seemed to me 62 both the one choir and the other to say “Amen!”, 63 that they clearly showed their desire for their mortal bodies:
64 perhaps not only for themselves, but for their mothers, 65 for their fathers and for the others who were dear 66 to them before they became eternal flames.
**Cornish:**
61 Kemmys hi a semlas dhe'm moy subit ha sprus 62 pub kethledh ha'n kethledh aral dhe leverel “Amen!”, 63 henna a wrug kler diskwedhes aga dysyr rag aga korfow marow:
64 marteth na genen rag aga honan, mes rag aga mammow, 65 rag aga tassyow ha rag an erel a via ker 66 kyns o vewa sempiternel flam.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Ed ecco intorno, di chiarezza pari, 68 nascere un lustro sopra quel che v’era, 69 per guisa d’orizzonte che rischiari.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And behold, all around, of equal brightness, 68 a splendor was born over that which was there, 69 in the manner of a horizon that grows light.
**Cornish:**
67 Ha'gas kovyn, a-dro, a sklerder par, 68 genys lustro a-ugh henna a via ena, 69 kepar dhe orison a wra'n sklerhe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 E sì come al salir di prima sera 71 comincian per lo ciel nove parvenze, 72 sì che la vista pare e non par vera,
73 parvemi lì novelle sussistenze 74 cominciare a vedere, e fare un giro 75 di fuor da l’altre due circunferenze.
query.result:
**English:**
70 And just as at the rising of early evening 71 new appearances begin in the sky, 72 so that the sight seems and does not seem real,
73 it seemed to me that new substances 74 began to appear there, and to make a circle 75 outside the other two circumferences.
**Cornish:**
70 Ha kepar dhe'n surrea a'n kynsa ser 71 a gomensa pub tra nowydh semlantys yn an ebron, 72 kepar dell an welas a seml ha na seml gwir,
73 henna a semlas dhe'm ena nowydh substansow 74 a gomensa dhe weles, ha gwruthyl kethledh 75 a-ves a'n dew kethledh aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Oh vero sfavillar del Santo Spiro! 77 come si fece sùbito e candente 78 a li occhi miei che, vinti, nol soffriro!
79 Ma Bëatrice sì bella e ridente 80 mi si mostrò, che tra quelle vedute 81 si vuol lasciar che non seguir la mente.
query.result:
**English:**
76 O true sparkling of the Holy Spirit! 77 How suddenly and brightly it became 78 to my eyes, which, overcome, could not bear it!
79 But Beatrice showed herself to me so beautiful and smiling 80 that among those visions 81 it is best to leave the mind not following her.
**Cornish:**
76 O gwir sfavillar a'n Sans Speris! 77 Kemmys hi a wrug subit ha gwyn 78 dhe'm lagha, a via gorhemmynys, na alla y soffri!
79 Mes Beatris a wrug kemmys hi a bell ha rident 80 dhe'm diskwedhes, henna ynter henna welasow 81 hi a wra gwell dhe golli an menes na'n sew.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Quindi ripreser li occhi miei virtute 83 a rilevarsi; e vidimi translato 84 sol con mia donna in più alta salute.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Then my eyes regained the power 83 to rise again; and I saw myself translated 84 alone with my lady to a higher salvation.
**Cornish:**
82 Wosa henna y'm lagha re'm lagha'm nerth 83 dhe'n surrea a-dhia; ha'm gwelas treylys 84 onan gans va'm benen dhe moy ughella iach.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Ben m’accors’ io ch’io era più levato, 86 per l’affocato riso de la stella, 87 che mi parea più roggio che l’usato.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Soon I realized that I had climbed higher, 86 because of the fiery glow of the star, 87 which seemed redder to me than usual.
**Cornish:**
85 Yn skon em gwelas vyth oen oedh ughella, 86 rag an golow rudh a'n steren, 87 hag ytho henna rudha ages re beu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Con tutto ’l core e con quella favella 89 ch’è una in tutti, a Dio feci olocausto, 90 qual conveniesi a la grazia novella.
query.result:
**English:**
88 With all my heart and in that language 89 which is the same for all, I made a burnt offering to God, 90 as is fitting for the new grace.
**Cornish:**
88 Gans ow colon ha gans an lavar ma, 89 eus eus dhe bub, dhe Dhew yth wra vy offryn, 90 kepar ha bos dhe'n gras nowydh.

**English:**
91 And the ardor of the sacrifice had not yet died down 92 in my breast, when I knew 93 that this act of worship had been accepted and was auspicious;
94 for with so much brightness and so many adornments 95 did two rays of light appear to me, 96 that I said: "O Helios, who adorns them so!"
**Cornish:**
91 Ha na veu kov an gwella a'm colon 92 an tan ow offryn, pan wrug vyth gorra 93 bos o veu dhe lowena.
94 Rag kemmys o splannder ha kemmys a addurnow 95 a welas vyth dhe'n dhew raggi, 96 wrug vyth leverel: "O Helyos, pyth yth addorn!"

**English:**
103 Here my memory overcomes my intellect; 104 for that cross flashed forth Christ, 105 so that I cannot find a worthy comparison;
106 but whoever takes up his cross and follows Christ, 107 will still excuse me for what I leave out, 108 seeing Christ flash forth in that radiance.
**Cornish:**
103 Ama, ow colon a veugh an gwella 104 rag an groes henna a splannder Krist, 105 wosa na'n jevon sampel dhe'n par.
106 Mes pyth a gymmer y'n groes ha'y sewya Krist, 107 ef a skus dha'm rag an pyth a lell, 108 wosa gweles Krist y'n splannder an gwella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Di corno in corno e tra la cima e ’l basso 110 si movien lumi, scintillando forte 111 nel congiugnersi insieme e nel trapasso:
112 così si veggion qui diritte e torte, 113 veloci e tarde, rinovando vista, 114 le minuzie d’i corpi, lunghe e corte,
115 moversi per lo raggio onde si lista 116 talvolta l’ombra che, per sua difesa, 117 la gente con ingegno e arte acquista.
query.result:
**English:**
109 From horn to horn and between the summit and the base 110 lights moved, sparkling brightly 111 as they joined together and passed by:
112 thus one sees here, straight and crooked, 113 swift and slow, renewing the sight, 114 the minute particles of bodies, long and short,
115 moving through the beam of light that sometimes streaks 116 the shadow which people, with ingenuity and skill, 117 acquire for their protection.
**Cornish:**
109 A-dhyworth horn dhe horn ha ynter an kodha ha'n nessa 110 a waya sterennow, ow splannder yn kreffa 111 pan o conjunja yn-nans ha pan o tremena:
112 kepar henna yma a weler straght ha kromm, 113 byghan ha meur, nowydhya an gweles, 114 an minuzyow a'n korfow, hir ha berr,
115 ow movyans dre an raggi a wra dhe'n list 116 an scouth a-whiles, pyth wra an bobel, gans gwella ha arta, 117 dhe'n gwaynya rag aga difens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 E come giga e arpa, in tempra tesa 119 di molte corde, fa dolce tintinno 120 a tal da cui la nota non è intesa,
121 così da’ lumi che lì m’apparinno 122 s’accogliea per la croce una melode 123 che mi rapiva, sanza intender l’inno.
query.result:
**English:**
118 And just as a zither and a harp, in tight tension 119 of many strings, make a sweet tinkling sound 120 to someone who does not understand the notes,
121 so from the lights that appeared to me there 122 a melody was gathered around the cross 123 that enraptured me, without my understanding the hymn.
**Cornish:**
118 Ha kepar ha giga ha harp, yn tempra tes, 119 a-dhyworth meur a gord, ow wra tintynyow doweth 120 dhe unn na wra an nota gans dhyworth,
121 kepar henna a'n sterennow a welas vyth ama 122 o conjunja rag an groes melodi 123 a wra vyth rapya, hebma gorra an hymn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Ben m’accors’ io ch’elli era d’alte lode, 125 però ch’a me venìa «Resurgi» e «Vinci» 126 come a colui che non intende e ode.
query.result:
**English:**
124 I realized well that it was a song of high praise, 125 because the words "Resurgi" and "Vinci" came to me 126 as to someone who hears but does not understand.
**Cornish:**
124 Ytho vyth gorra vyth o veu kanow canow, 125 rag dhe'n gerow "Resurgi" ha "Vinci" a dheuth dhe'm 126 kepar dhe unn na wra gorra ha klevs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ïo m’innamorava tanto quinci, 128 che ’nfino a lì non fu alcuna cosa 129 che mi legasse con sì dolci vinci.
query.result:
**English:**
127 I was so enraptured by this, 128 that up to that point there had been nothing 129 that had bound me with such sweet bonds.
**Cornish:**
127 Vyth o veu ena enamorys kemmys, 128 wosa bys intya na veu unn travyth 129 a wra vyth kevel gans vinci kemmys doweth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Forse la mia parola par troppo osa, 131 posponendo il piacer de li occhi belli, 132 ne’ quai mirando mio disio ha posa;
133 ma chi s’avvede che i vivi suggelli 134 d’ogne bellezza più fanno più suso, 135 e ch’io non m’era lì rivolto a quelli,
136 escusar puommi di quel ch’io m’accuso 137 per escusarmi, e vedermi dir vero: 138 ché ’l piacer santo non è qui dischiuso,
139 perché si fa, montando, più sincero.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Perhaps my words seem too bold, 131 in setting aside the pleasure of the beautiful eyes, 132 in gazing upon which my desire finds repose;
133 but whoever realizes that the living seals 134 of every beauty shine more brightly above, 135 and that I had not turned to them there,
136 can excuse me for what I accuse myself of 137 in order to excuse myself, and see that I am telling the truth: 138 for holy pleasure is not revealed here,
139 because it becomes purer as one ascends.
**Cornish:**
130 Mar pleg vyth lavar a wra ges re bold, 131 ow pospona an plijadow a'n golwgow brassa, 132 y'n mys a weles ow dysyr a wra posa;
133 mes pyth a wra gorra wosa an selys byw 134 a bub brassa a wra gwella moy uhella, 135 ha wosa vyth na veu ena troys dhe'n selys,
136 a alla vyth eskusa rag an pyth a wra vyth akusa 137 rag vyth eskusa, ha gweles vyth leverel an gwir: 138 rag an plijadow sans na wra ama diskluys,
139 rag ytho henna ow wra moy bur ow montya.
